DataElement.preferredName: Study Protocol Investigational New Drug Or Investigational Medical Device Exemption Flag National Institutes of Health Holder Code NihInstituteHolderCode
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.:A rule which guides how an activity should be performed.:A new drug or biological drug that is used in a clinical investigation. The term also includes a biological product that is used in vitro for diagnostic purposes.:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:A device that is the subject of clinical investigation or research to determine the safety or effectiveness of the device. Investigational devices include transitional devices (21 CFR 812.3(r)) that are objects of investigations. An investigational device may be an approved device that is being studied for an unapproved use or efficacy.:Immunity from an obligation or duty.:An indicator that can be set or unset in order to signal whether a particular condition is true._An agency of the PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE concerned with the overall planning, promoting, and administering of programs pertaining to health and medical research.:A person who has physical possession or legal rights to something.:A symbol or combination of symbols which is given an arbitrary meaning within a systematized collection of concepts used for data representation._The code that identifes the name of the NIH Institute.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Study Protocol Investigational New Drug Or Investigational Medical Device Exemption Flag
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.:A rule which guides how an activity should be performed.:A new drug or biological drug that is used in a clinical investigation. The term also includes a biological product that is used in vitro for diagnostic purposes.:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:A device that is the subject of clinical investigation or research to determine the safety or effectiveness of the device. Investigational devices include transitional devices (21 CFR 812.3(r)) that are objects of investigations. Concepts.definition: A detailed examination, analysis, or critical inspection of a subject designed to discover facts about it.
A rule which guides how an activity should be performed.
A new drug or biological drug that is used in a clinical investigation. The term also includes a biological product that is used in vitro for diagnostic purposes.

An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

A device that is the subject of clinical investigation or research to determine the safety or effectiveness of the device. Investigational devices include transitional devices (21 CFR 812.3(r)) that are objects of investigations. An investigational device may be an approved device that is being studied for an unapproved use or efficacy.
Immunity from an obligation or duty.
An indicator that can be set or unset in order to signal whether a particular condition is true.

Property.preferredName: National Institutes of Health Holder Code
Property.preferredDefinition: An agency of the PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE concerned with the overall planning, promoting, and administering of programs pertaining to health and medical research.:A person who has physical possession or legal rights to something.:A symbol or combination of symbols which is given an arbitrary meaning within a systematized collection of concepts used for data representation.

Concepts.definition: A federal agency in the U.S. that conducts biomedical research in its own laboratories; supports the research of non-Federal scientists in universities, medical schools, hospitals, and research institutions throughout the country and abroad; helps in the training of research investigators; and fosters communication of medical information. Access the National Institutes of Health Web site at http://www.nih.gov.
A person who has physical possession or legal rights to something.
A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: 7/22/2021wz: released for UML model cleanup project.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The code that identifes the name of the NIH Institute.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Clinical Center

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Clinical Center
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The research hospital for the NIH, the Federal Government's principal agency for biomedical research. The NIH Clinical Center is actually made up of two centers: the Warren Grant Magnuson Clinical Center and the Mark O. Hatfield Clinical Research Center. The Clinical Center as a whole promotes translational research, that is, the transformation of scientific laboratory research into applications that benefit patient health and medical care. At the Center, patient care units are in close proximity to cutting-edge technologies and laboratories doing related research. This "bench-to-bedside" approach facilitates interaction and collaboration among clinicians and researchers. The Clinical Center supports clinical trials conducted by the 27 Institutes and Centers of the NIH, including the National Cancer Institute (NCI).

Concepts.definition: The research hospital for the NIH, the Federal Government's principal agency for biomedical research. The NIH Clinical Center is actually made up of two centers: the Warren Grant Magnuson Clinical Center and the Mark O. Hatfield Clinical Research Center. The Clinical Center as a whole promotes translational research, that is, the transformation of scientific laboratory research into applications that benefit patient health and medical care. At the Center, patient care units are in close proximity to cutting-edge technologies and laboratories doing related research. This "bench-to-bedside" approach facilitates interaction and collaboration among clinicians and researchers. The Clinical Center supports clinical trials conducted by the 27 Institutes and Centers of the NIH, including the National Cancer Institute (NCI).

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: NIH Center for Scientific Review

ValueMeaning.preferredName: NIH Center for Scientific Review
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The Center for Scientific Review (CSR) provides staff support to the Office of the Director, NIH, in the formulation of grant application review policies and procedures. In addition, CSR provides central receipt of all PHS applications for research and review.

Concepts.definition: Provides staff support to the Office of the Director, NIH, in the formulation of grant application review policies and procedures. In addition, CSR provides central receipt of all PHS applications for research and review.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Fogarty International Center

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Fogarty International Center
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The international component of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) dedicated to advancing the mission of NIH by supporting and facilitating global health research conducted by U.S. and international investigators, building partnerships between health research institutions in the U.S. and abroad, and training the next generation of scientists to address global health needs.

Concepts.definition: The international component of the National Institutes of Health (NIH) dedicated to advancing the mission of NIH by supporting and facilitating global health research conducted by U.S. and international investigators, building partnerships between health research institutions in the U.S. and abroad, and training the next generation of scientists to address global health needs.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that provides global leadership for a research, training, and education program to promote the prevention and treatment of heart, lung, and blood diseases and enhance the health of all individuals so that they can live longer and more fulfilling lives.

Concepts.longName: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that provides global leadership for a research, training, and education program to promote the prevention and treatment of heart, lung, and blood diseases and enhance the health of all individuals so that they can live longer and more fulfilling lives.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that conducts and supports basic and applied research to better understand, treat, and ultimately prevent infectious, immunologic, and allergic diseases.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that conducts and supports basic and applied research to better understand, treat, and ultimately prevent infectious, immunologic, and allergic diseases.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to reduce the burden of human illness and disability by understanding how the environment influences the development and progression of human disease.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to reduce the burden of human illness and disability by understanding how the environment influences the development and progression of human disease.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Mental Health

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Mental Health
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to transform the understanding and treatment of mental illnesses through basic and clinical research, paving the way for prevention, recovery and cure.

Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to transform the understanding and treatment of mental illnesses through basic and clinical research, paving the way for prevention, recovery and cure.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Library of Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Library of Medicine
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A division of the National Institutes of Health, it is the world's largest biomedical library. The Library is involved in development of electronic sevices.  Its mission is to enable biomedical research, support health care and public health, and promote healthy behavior.

Concepts.definition: A division of the National Institutes of Health, it is the world's largest biomedical library. The Library is involved in development of electronic sevices.  Its mission is to enable biomedical research, support health care and public health, and promote healthy behavior.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Office of the Director

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Office of the Director
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Office of the NCI Director serves as the focal point for the National Cancer Program; develops a National Cancer Plan and monitors implementation of the plan; directs and coordinates the Institute's programs and activities; and develops and provides policy guidance and staff direction to the Institute's programs in areas such as program coordination, program planning, clinical care and administrative management.

Concepts.definition: Office of the NCI Director serves as the focal point for the National Cancer Program; develops a National Cancer Plan and monitors implementation of the plan; directs and coordinates the Institute's programs and activities; and develops and provides policy guidance and staff direction to the Institute's programs in areas such as program coordination, program planning, clinical care and administrative management.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that conducts and supports research on all stages of human development from preconception to adulthood, to better understand the health of children, adults, families, and communities.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Child Health and Human Development
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that conducts and supports research on all stages of human development from preconception to adulthood, to better understand the health of children, adults, families, and communities.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to improve health by leading the development and accelerating the application of biomedical technologies. The Institute is committed to integrating the physical and engineering sciences with the life sciences, to advance basic research and medical care.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Biomedical Imaging and Bioengineering
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to improve health by leading the development and accelerating the application of biomedical technologies. The Institute is committed to integrating the physical and engineering sciences with the life sciences, to advance basic research and medical care.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that supports research into the causes, treatment, and prevention of arthritis and musculoskeletal and skin diseases, the training of basic and clinical scientists to carry out this research, and the dissemination of information on research progress in these diseases.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that supports research into the causes, treatment, and prevention of arthritis and musculoskeletal and skin diseases, the training of basic and clinical scientists to carry out this research, and the dissemination of information on research progress in these diseases.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that provides leadership in the national effort to reduce alcohol-related problems.

Concepts.longName: National Institute on Alcohol Abuse and Alcoholism
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that provides leadership in the national effort to reduce alcohol-related problems.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute on Drug Abuse

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute on Drug Abuse
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to lead the nation in bringing the power of science to bear on drug abuse and addiction. This charge has two critical components, the strategic support and conduct of research across a broad range of disciplines and the rapid and effective dissemination and use of the results of that research to significantly improve prevention, treatment and policy as it relates to drug abuse and addiction.

Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to lead the nation in bringing the power of science to bear on drug abuse and addiction. This charge has two critical components, the strategic support and conduct of research across a broad range of disciplines and the rapid and effective dissemination and use of the results of that research to significantly improve prevention, treatment and policy as it relates to drug abuse and addiction.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that conducts and supports much of the clinical research on the diseases of internal medicine and related subspecialty fields, as well as many basic science disciplines.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that conducts and supports much of the clinical research on the diseases of internal medicine and related subspecialty fields, as well as many basic science disciplines.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the institutes that comprise the National Institutes of Health. The mission of the NIDCR is to improve oral, dental and craniofacial health through research, research training, and the dissemination of health information.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research
Concepts.definition: One of the institutes that comprise the National Institutes of Health. The mission of the NIDCR is to improve oral, dental and craniofacial health through research, research training, and the dissemination of health information.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that is mandated to conduct and support biomedical and behavioral research and research training in the normal and disordered processes of hearing, balance, smell, taste, voice, speech, and language.

Concepts.longName: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that is mandated to conduct and support biomedical and behavioral research and research training in the normal and disordered processes of hearing, balance, smell, taste, voice, speech, and language.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute on Aging

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute on Aging
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that leads a broad scientific effort to understand the nature of aging and to extend the healthy, active years of life.

Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health that leads a broad scientific effort to understand the nature of aging and to extend the healthy, active years of life.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Human Genome Research Institute

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Human Genome Research Institute
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health (NIH) that led NIH's contribution to the International Human Genome Project. Since the completion of this project its mission has expanded to encompass a broad range of studies aimed at understanding the structure and function of the human genome and its role in health and disease. To that end it supports the development of resources and technology that will accelerate genome research and its application to human health. A critical part of its mission continues to be the study of the ethical, legal and social implications (ELSI) of genome research.

Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health (NIH) that led NIH's contribution to the International Human Genome Project. Since the completion of this project its mission has expanded to encompass a broad range of studies aimed at understanding the structure and function of the human genome and its role in health and disease. To that end it supports the development of resources and technology that will accelerate genome research and its application to human health. A critical part of its mission continues to be the study of the ethical, legal and social implications (ELSI) of genome research.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Eye Institute

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Eye Institute
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to conduct and support research, training, health information dissemination, and other programs with respect to blinding eye diseases, visual disorders, mechanisms of visual function, preservation of sight, and the special health problems and requirements of the blind.

Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to conduct and support research, training, health information dissemination, and other programs with respect to blinding eye diseases, visual disorders, mechanisms of visual function, preservation of sight, and the special health problems and requirements of the blind.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Center for Information Technology

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Center for Information Technology
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A center within the National Institutes of Health that provides, coordinates, and manages information technology, and advances computational science within NIH.

Concepts.definition: A center within the National Institutes of Health that provides, coordinates, and manages information technology, and advances computational science within NIH.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Nursing Research

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Nursing Research
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to promote and improve the health of individuals, families, communities, and populations. It supports and conducts clinical and basic research and research training on health and illness across the lifespan.

Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to promote and improve the health of individuals, families, communities, and populations. It supports and conducts clinical and basic research and research training on health and illness across the lifespan.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to reduce the burden of neurological disease by conducting and funding research on brain and nervous system disorders.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to reduce the burden of neurological disease by conducting and funding research on brain and nervous system disorders.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Institute of General Medical Sciences

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Institute of General Medical Sciences
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS) primarily supports basic biomedical research that is not targeted to specific diseases or disorders.

Concepts.longName: National Institute of General Medical Sciences
Concepts.definition: The National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS) primarily supports basic biomedical research that is not targeted to specific diseases or disorders.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Center for Research Resources

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Center for Research Resources
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A center within the National Institutes of Health that provides laboratory scientists and clinical researchers with the tools and training they need to understand, detect, treat, and prevent a wide range of diseases.

Concepts.definition: A center within the National Institutes of Health that provides laboratory scientists and clinical researchers with the tools and training they need to understand, detect, treat, and prevent a wide range of diseases.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Center on Minority Health and Health Disparities

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Center on Minority Health and Health Disparities
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A center within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to promote minority health and to lead, coordinate, support, and assess the NIH effort to reduce and ultimately eliminate health disparities.

Concepts.longName: National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities
Concepts.definition: An institute within the National Institutes of Health with the mission to promote minority health and to lead, coordinate, support, and assess the NIH effort to reduce and ultimately eliminate health disparities.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredName: National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A center within the National Institutes of Health that acts as the Federal Government's lead agency for scientific research on the diverse medical and health care systems, practices, and products that are not generally considered part of conventional medicine.

Concepts.longName: National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine
Concepts.definition: A center within the National Institutes of Health that acts as the Federal Government's lead agency for scientific research on the diverse medical and health care systems, practices, and products that are not generally considered part of conventional medicine.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the management of a research protocol and its case report forms.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A system of numbered categories for representation of data.

Concepts.definition: A symbol or combination of symbols which is assigned to the members of a collection.
